Violation_Type: Failure to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably concluded the applicant failed to rebut the presumption of state protection
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Application_Facts: Ms. Rangel Macias, a Mexican lawyer and human rights activist, claimed refugee status in Canada due to threats in Mexico; she approached neighborhood police but did not pursue further state protection
Remedy_Requested: Certification of a question and allowance of judicial review
Court_Ruling: The Federal Court found the Board's decision reasonable
Claimant_Status: Mexican national, lawyer, human rights activist
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear for safety due to threats received in Mexico
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of applicant, reasonableness of steps taken to seek state protection
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found Ms. Rangel Macias credible
Evidence_Used: Testimony of Ms. Rangel Macias, record of interactions with local police
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Claim of risk to life and safety in Mexico due to activism
Evidence_Assessed: Nature and extent of engagement with Mexican law enforcement
Governing_Rule: Applicant must provide clear and convincing evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to exhaust available avenues of state protection in Mexico
Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; application for judicial review dismissed
Harm_Assessment: Perceived risk due to threats as a human rights activist
Cause_Description: Ms. Rangel Macias sought refugee status in Canada after receiving threats in Mexico, claiming fear for her safety
Evidence_Handling: Board assessed credibility and sufficiency of efforts to seek protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Presumption of state protection under IRPA
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient evidence of attempts to access formal state protection mechanisms
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicantâ€™s actions deemed insufficient to rebut state protection presumption
Decision_Rationale: Board reasonably concluded applicant did not take reasonable steps to seek state protection in Mexico
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of documentation or follow-up with higher-level authorities in Mexico
